frontmatter.title: Radical ideals bijectively correspond to open sets

mainmatter.p: In an arbitrary topological spectrum of a commutative ring, we have D( \mathfrak { a } ) = D( \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } })D(a)=D(a)D( \mathfrak { a } ) = D( \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } })D(a)=D(a​). There is a containment of opens D( \mathfrak { a } ) \subseteq D( \mathfrak { b } )D(a)⊆D(b)D( \mathfrak { a } ) \subseteq D( \mathfrak { b } )D(a)⊆D(b) — equivalently V( \mathfrak { b } ) \subseteq V( \mathfrak { a } )V(b)⊆V(a)V( \mathfrak { b } ) \subseteq V( \mathfrak { a } )V(b)⊆V(a) — iff \sqrt { \mathfrak { b } } \mid \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } }b∣a\sqrt { \mathfrak { b } } \mid \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } }b​∣a​, and the points contained in an open set completely determines the radical ideal.

Since \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a\mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a implies \sqrt { \mathfrak { p } } \mid \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } }p∣a\sqrt { \mathfrak { p } } \mid \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } }p​∣a​, but \mathfrak { p } = \sqrt { \mathfrak { p } }p=p\mathfrak { p } = \sqrt { \mathfrak { p } }p=p​, we see that D( \mathfrak { a } ) = D( \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } })D(a)=D(a)D( \mathfrak { a } ) = D( \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } })D(a)=D(a​). We just have to prove the forward implication of the last statement. Suppose for all prime ideals \mathfrak { p }p\mathfrak { p }p we have \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { b } \implies \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣b  ⟹  p∣a\mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { b } \implies \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣b⟹p∣a. We need to prove that \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } } \mid f \implies \sqrt { \mathfrak { b } } \mid fa∣f  ⟹  b∣f\sqrt { \mathfrak { a } } \mid f \implies \sqrt { \mathfrak { b } } \mid fa​∣f⟹b​∣f.

Given \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } } \mid fa∣f\sqrt { \mathfrak { a } } \mid fa​∣f, we have \mathfrak { p } \mid fp∣f\mathfrak { p } \mid fp∣f for all prime ideals \mathfrak { p } \mid \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } }p∣a\mathfrak { p } \mid \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } }p∣a​ (which is equivalent to \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a\mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a). So we know that for all \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { b }p∣b\mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { b }p∣b, \mathfrak { p } \mid fp∣f\mathfrak { p } \mid fp∣f. This is now purely a condition on \mathfrak { b }b\mathfrak { b }b. The next lemma finishes the proof.

frontmatter.title: The radical ideal is the lcm of prime ideal divisors

mainmatter.p: For any ideal \mathfrak { a }a\mathfrak { a }a of a commutative ring, the radical \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } }a\sqrt { \mathfrak { a } }a​ is the lowest common multiple of the prime ideals \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a\mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a.

On one hand, if \sqrt { \mathfrak { a } } \mid fa∣f\sqrt { \mathfrak { a } } \mid fa​∣f, then \mathfrak { a } \mid f^na∣fn\mathfrak { a } \mid f^na∣fn for some natural number nnnn. This means for all \mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a\mathfrak { p } \mid \mathfrak { a }p∣a, we have \mathfrak { p } \mid f^np∣fn\mathfrak { p } \mid f^np∣fn, which by being a prime ideal implies \mathfrak { p } \mid fp∣f\mathfrak { p } \mid fp∣f.

frontmatter.title: Topological spectrum of a commutative ring

mainmatter.p: The topological spectrum of a commutative ring RRRR, denoted \operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec⁡(R)\operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec(R), is a topological space whose points are given by prime ideals of RRRR. We denote the point corresponding to \mathfrak { p }p\mathfrak { p }p as \left [ \mathfrak { p } \right ][p]\left [ \mathfrak { p } \right ][p]. We define an open D( \mathfrak { a } )D(a)D( \mathfrak { a } )D(a) for each ideal \mathfrak { a }a\mathfrak { a }a which contains the point \left [ \mathfrak { p } \right ][p]\left [ \mathfrak { p } \right ][p] when \mathfrak { p } \nmid \mathfrak { a }p∤a\mathfrak { p } \nmid \mathfrak { a }p∤a. The corresponding closed is written as V( \mathfrak { a } )V(a)V( \mathfrak { a } )V(a).
We abuse the notation and write D(f)D(f)D(f)D(f) for the case where \mathfrak { a }a\mathfrak { a }a is generated by ffff. Similar notations apply to VVVV.

frontmatter.title: Irreducible closeds in a ring spectrum

mainmatter.p: A closed V( \mathfrak { r } )V(r)V( \mathfrak { r } )V(r) in \operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec⁡(R)\operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec(R) is irreducible iff \mathfrak { r }r\mathfrak { r }r is prime, and it is an irreducible component iff \mathfrak { r }r\mathfrak { r }r is a minimal prime ideal, i.e. prime ideals that divide no other prime ideals.

Translating via , we have a proper ideal \mathfrak { r }r\mathfrak { r }r that cannot be written as \operatorname {lcm} ( \mathfrak { r } _1, \mathfrak { r } _2)lcm⁡(r1,r2)\operatorname {lcm} ( \mathfrak { r } _1, \mathfrak { r } _2)lcm(r1​,r2​) non-trivially. Suppose \mathfrak { r } \mid f gr∣fg\mathfrak { r } \mid f gr∣fg, then \mathfrak { r } \mid \sqrt {f g} \mid \operatorname {lcm} (f, g)r∣fg∣lcm⁡(f,g)\mathfrak { r } \mid \sqrt {f g} \mid \operatorname {lcm} (f, g)r∣fg​∣lcm(f,g). So \begin {aligned} \mathfrak { r } &= \gcd ( \mathfrak { r } , \operatorname {lcm} (f, g)) \\ &= \operatorname {lcm} ( \gcd ( \mathfrak { r } , f), \gcd ( \mathfrak { r } , g)). \end {aligned}r=gcd⁡(r,lcm⁡(f,g))=lcm⁡(gcd⁡(r,f),gcd⁡(r,g)).\begin {aligned} \mathfrak { r } &= \gcd ( \mathfrak { r } , \operatorname {lcm} (f, g)) \\ &= \operatorname {lcm} ( \gcd ( \mathfrak { r } , f), \gcd ( \mathfrak { r } , g)). \end {aligned}r​=gcd(r,lcm(f,g))=lcm(gcd(r,f),gcd(r,g)).​ Hence at least one of the two must be equal to \mathfrak { r }r\mathfrak { r }r. So \mathfrak { r } \mid fr∣f\mathfrak { r } \mid fr∣f or \mathfrak { r } \mid gr∣g\mathfrak { r } \mid gr∣g.
An irreducible closed is an irreducible component if it is contained in no other irreducible closed. We immediately get the definition of minimal prime ideals translating to the algebraic realm.

frontmatter.title: Structure sheaf of a ring spectrum

mainmatter.p: Given a commutative ring RRRR, we define a sheaf \mathscr { O }O\mathscr { O }O of rings on \operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec⁡(R)\operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec(R) called the structure sheaf. Let \Gamma (D(f), \mathscr { O } ) = R[f^{-1}]Γ(D(f),O)=R[f−1]\Gamma (D(f), \mathscr { O } ) = R[f^{-1}]Γ(D(f),O)=R[f−1]. Suppose D(f) \subseteq D(g)D(f)⊆D(g)D(f) \subseteq D(g)D(f)⊆D(g) we define the restriction morphism to be the localization map R[g^{-1}] \to R[f^{-1}]R[g−1]→R[f−1]R[g^{-1}] \to R[f^{-1}]R[g−1]→R[f−1], since by the latter is a further localization of the former. This turns \operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec⁡(R)\operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec(R) into a ringed space.

We just need to verify the sheaf axioms on the bases, i.e. given a family of elements f_i \in Rfi∈Rf_i \in Rfi​∈R such that \bigcup _i D(f_i) = D(f)⋃iD(fi)=D(f)\bigcup _i D(f_i) = D(f)⋃i​D(fi​)=D(f), we need to show that R[f^{-1}] \to \prod _{i \in I} R[f_i^{-1}] \rightrightarrows \prod _{i \ne j} R[(f_i f_j)^{-1}]R[f−1]→∏i∈IR[fi−1]⇉∏i≠jR[(fifj)−1]R[f^{-1}] \to \prod _{i \in I} R[f_i^{-1}] \rightrightarrows \prod _{i \ne j} R[(f_i f_j)^{-1}]R[f−1]→i∈I∏​R[fi−1​]⇉i=j∏​R[(fi​fj​)−1] is an equalizer. Notice that R[f_i^{-1}] \cong R[f^{-1}][f_i^{-1}]R[fi−1]≅R[f−1][fi−1]R[f_i^{-1}] \cong R[f^{-1}][f_i^{-1}]R[fi−1​]≅R[f−1][fi−1​]. So we may reassign S = R[f^{-1}]S=R[f−1]S = R[f^{-1}]S=R[f−1]. This simplifies the problem to S \to \prod _{i \in I} S[f_i^{-1}] \rightrightarrows \prod _{i \ne j} S[(f_i f_j)^{-1}],S→∏i∈IS[fi−1]⇉∏i≠jS[(fifj)−1],S \to \prod _{i \in I} S[f_i^{-1}] \rightrightarrows \prod _{i \ne j} S[(f_i f_j)^{-1}],S→i∈I∏​S[fi−1​]⇉i=j∏​S[(fi​fj​)−1], where D(f_i)D(fi)D(f_i)D(fi​) covers the whole space \operatorname {Spec} (S)Spec⁡(S)\operatorname {Spec} (S)Spec(S).

We first describe the intuition. Since we know \operatorname {Spec} (S)Spec⁡(S)\operatorname {Spec} (S)Spec(S) is quasi-compact, we can roughly expect to reduce the problem to finite cases. Localization is a bit complicated due to zero-divisors, but suppose we don’t have them, we have elements g_i/f_i^{d_i} \in S[f_i^{-1}]gi/fidi∈S[fi−1]g_i/f_i^{d_i} \in S[f_i^{-1}]gi​/fidi​​∈S[fi−1​] that are equal in their common domain. Since D(f_i) = D(f_i^{d_i})D(fi)=D(fidi)D(f_i) = D(f_i^{d_i})D(fi​)=D(fidi​​) covers \operatorname {Spec} (S)Spec⁡(S)\operatorname {Spec} (S)Spec(S), we have a linear combination 1 = \sum _i c_i f_i^{d_i}1=∑icifidi1 = \sum _i c_i f_i^{d_i}1=∑i​ci​fidi​​, which is akin to a partition of unity. Suppose the putative gluing is ffff, multiplying with the partition of unity we get \begin {aligned} f &= \sum _{i \in I} c_i f_i^{d_i} f \\ &= \sum c_i f_i^{d_i} \frac {g_i}{f_i^{d_i}} \\ &= \sum c_i g_i. \end {aligned}f=∑i∈Icifidif=∑cifidigifidi=∑cigi.\begin {aligned} f &= \sum _{i \in I} c_i f_i^{d_i} f \\ &= \sum c_i f_i^{d_i} \frac {g_i}{f_i^{d_i}} \\ &= \sum c_i g_i. \end {aligned}f​=i∈I∑​ci​fidi​​f=∑ci​fidi​​fidi​​gi​​=∑ci​gi​.​ which defines the gluing. We just have to make this reasoning precise. We first deal with the finite case.

Suppose there are elements g_i/f_i^d \in S[f_i^{-1}]gi/fid∈S[fi−1]g_i/f_i^d \in S[f_i^{-1}]gi​/fid​∈S[fi−1​], where we are allowed to use a single exponent dddd by finiteness. The compatibility requirement is (g_i f_j^d - g_j f_i^d) (f_i f_j)^{N} = 0.(gifjd−gjfid)(fifj)N=0.(g_i f_j^d - g_j f_i^d) (f_i f_j)^{N} = 0.(gi​fjd​−gj​fid​)(fi​fj​)N=0. If there is a solution ffff to the gluing problem, it would need to satisfy (f f_i^d - g_i) f_i^M = 0(ffid−gi)fiM=0(f f_i^d - g_i) f_i^M = 0(ffid​−gi​)fiM​=0. Since D(f_i) = D(f_i^R)D(fi)=D(fiR)D(f_i) = D(f_i^R)D(fi​)=D(fiR​) covers \operatorname {Spec} (S)Spec⁡(S)\operatorname {Spec} (S)Spec(S), we have a linear combination 1 = \sum _i c_i f_i^R1=∑icifiR1 = \sum _i c_i f_i^R1=∑i​ci​fiR​ for large enough RRRR. Hence f = \sum _{i \in I} c_i f f_i^R = \sum c_i g_i f_i^{R-d}.f=∑i∈IciffiR=∑cigifiR−d.f = \sum _{i \in I} c_i f f_i^R = \sum c_i g_i f_i^{R-d}.f=i∈I∑​ci​ffiR​=∑ci​gi​fiR−d​. This uniquely determines ffff. And indeed, this solution satisfies our requirements, because when restricted to D(f_j)D(fj)D(f_j)D(fj​), we have \begin {aligned} f f_j^d \cdot f_j^R &= \sum c_i g_i f_i^{R-d} f_j^{R+d} \\ &= \sum c_i g_j f_i^{R} f_j^{R} \\ &= g_j f_j^R \cdot \sum c_i f_i^R = g_j f_j^R. \end {aligned}ffjd⋅fjR=∑cigifiR−dfjR+d=∑cigjfiRfjR=gjfjR⋅∑cifiR=gjfjR.\begin {aligned} f f_j^d \cdot f_j^R &= \sum c_i g_i f_i^{R-d} f_j^{R+d} \\ &= \sum c_i g_j f_i^{R} f_j^{R} \\ &= g_j f_j^R \cdot \sum c_i f_i^R = g_j f_j^R. \end {aligned}ffjd​⋅fjR​​=∑ci​gi​fiR−d​fjR+d​=∑ci​gj​fiR​fjR​=gj​fjR​⋅∑ci​fiR​=gj​fjR​.​ This reasoning is valid as long as R > N + 2dR>N+2dR > N + 2dR>N+2d.

If there are infinitely many opens, we first use quasi-compactness to select a finite number D(f_1), \dots , D(f_k)D(f1),…,D(fk)D(f_1), \dots , D(f_k)D(f1​),…,D(fk​) that covers the whole space. The uniqueness of gluing solutions in the finite case implies that of the infinite case. For existence, first take the solution ffff for D(f_1), \dots , D(f_k)D(f1),…,D(fk)D(f_1), \dots , D(f_k)D(f1​),…,D(fk​). Then consider the solution on D(f_1), \dots , D(f_k) , D(g)D(f1),…,D(fk),D(g)D(f_1), \dots , D(f_k) , D(g)D(f1​),…,D(fk​),D(g) for every gggg. This solution must be equal to ffff by uniqueness. Therefore ffff restrict to the correct function on each D(g)D(g)D(g)D(g), showing that ffff is the required solution.

frontmatter.title: Characterization of the locale \operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec⁡(R)\operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec(R)

mainmatter.p: The opens in the locale \operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec⁡(R)\operatorname {Spec} (R)Spec(R) bijectively corresponds to radical ideals of RRRR, whose divisibility relation agree with the inverse inclusion relation of opens. Intersections correspond to lowest common multiple, and unions correspond to the radical of the greatest common divisor. In other words, the locale is isomorphic to the locale corresponding to the topological spectrum of a commutative ring by .

We can first put the opens in disjunctive normal form U = \bigcup _{i \in I} \bigcap _{j=1}^{n_i} D(f_{i, j}).U=⋃i∈I⋂j=1niD(fi,j).U = \bigcup _{i \in I} \bigcap _{j=1}^{n_i} D(f_{i, j}).U=i∈I⋃​j=1⋂ni​​D(fi,j​). By the definition we can reduce the intersections into products. Write f_i = \prod _j f_{i, j}fi=∏jfi,jf_i = \prod _j f_{i, j}fi​=∏j​fi,j​, we have U = \bigcup _i D(f_i)U=⋃iD(fi)U = \bigcup _i D(f_i)U=⋃i​D(fi​). Given this form, we can try to saturate the union, by throwing in everything that doesn’t enlarge UUUU. In other words, we only consider the unions such that no other generator D(f)D(f)D(f)D(f) can be added, i.e. D(f) \nsubseteq UD(f)⊈UD(f) \nsubseteq UD(f)⊈U. This would uniquely determine UUUU.

Such a saturated set would have to be closed under addition since D(f+g) \subseteq D(f) \cup D(g)D(f+g)⊆D(f)∪D(g)D(f+g) \subseteq D(f) \cup D(g)D(f+g)⊆D(f)∪D(g), and for the nullary case it must include D(0) = \botD(0)=⊥D(0) = \botD(0)=⊥. It also has to absorb multiplication, because D(f \cdot g) \subseteq D(f)D(f⋅g)⊆D(f)D(f \cdot g) \subseteq D(f)D(f⋅g)⊆D(f). This means we are dealing with ideals. Henceforth, we write D( \mathfrak { a } )D(a)D( \mathfrak { a } )D(a) for the union \bigcup _{ \mathfrak { a } \mid f} D(f)⋃a∣fD(f)\bigcup _{ \mathfrak { a } \mid f} D(f)⋃a∣f​D(f).

There is one last requirement we haven’t dealt with, i.e. D(f \cdot g)D(f⋅g)D(f \cdot g)D(f⋅g) is the greatest lower bound of D(f)D(f)D(f)D(f) and D(g)D(g)D(g)D(g), instead of simply a lower bound. For example, this gives the equality D(f^n) = D(f)D(fn)=D(f)D(f^n) = D(f)D(fn)=D(f), so we need to restrict our attention to radical ideals. It then suffices to prove that the radical ideal generated by f \cdot gf⋅gf \cdot gf⋅g is equal to the lowest common multiple of the radical ideals generated by ffff and gggg, which is true.
